instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
Hi i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B With water damage, it wont power on and only has a green light. I have checked the <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> pin 4=3.26mv pin A & B= 3.26mv pin 5= 3.4mv & <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> pin 4=3.72mv pin 1 =3.27mv <CAPACITOR>C6908</CAPACITOR>=3.4mv.  is the dip in mv from 3.72 to 3.27 and 3.4mv a problem?  im going to keep digging into this. any help is appreciated 
Thanks
Nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
PPBUS voltagem should be 12.6V?
Corrosion around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?
Check <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and traces to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
okay i checked ppbus and im getting 12.56v
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 im getting 12.56 at both
<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 Im getting 18.24V
The <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> i dont see any obvious corrosion, but this board came in a little to clean for me so i wonder if it has been cleaned before. i could replace it to test if you thing i should.
Also <CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> im getting 12.37v and 17.36v but if not mistaking that should be 10v?
and only 3.4v at <CAPACITOR>C7002</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
Are you using a REAL 85W charger? It will not power on with anything less. Chinese chargers say 85W but many times they are fake 60W ones.
Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present (L7260)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message: Yes im using a genuine apple 85w charger. I Tested probe points 557 &365 for the L7260 and got 0v on both.  So should i replace the L7260?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
It makes no sense to replace a coil.
You test first if the enable signal is there, so is there voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL>? If yes then is there maybe a short to GND on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
Right.  
I have voltage at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> but i cant find <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus is it spelled different in the pdf? Sorry for my inexperience,  and thanks for all the help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_EN</SIGNAL> does not exist it is <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is a million times in the PDF, but it is coming from L7260.
So pin 21 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>(<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>) has 3.3V and there is nothing on L7260?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message: okay that makes sense i did assume that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> so i had tested that correctly. im getting 3.4v at pin 21 of the <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. but nothing on the L7260, i checked probe 365 & 557 both gave me 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message: Looks like an issue with <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Measure pins 12,13,22,23,29. What is resistance to GND on L7260?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message:
I tested the <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> 
Pin 12 =3.49v
pin 13 =2v
pin 22 =3.3v
pin 23 =12.56v
pin 29 =5v

I tested resistance to GND on the L7260 with 16.5-16.9 ohms on both pins 1 & 2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power no orange light
threads.message: 16 ohm to GND on L7260 is too low. There is something not right on the 3V3 bus. You can inject 3V3 on L7260 and see if anything heats up, but 16 ohm is a semi short so this may be difficult to track down.
